properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Snow squalls will be possible this evening as strong winds help snow bands penetrate far inland from Lake Huron. Travel may be hazardous at times due to heavy snow and blowing snow reducing visibilities and rapidly changing conditions. Local snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm will be possible by midnight. The lake effect snow bands will then weaken into a few flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T13:59:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T00:31:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0317074801.2019
Area: Simcoe - Delhi - Norfolk, St. Thomas - Aylmer - Eastern Elgin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values of minus 30 are expected tonight into Thursday morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T07:48:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-18T15:49:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3098984241.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow over the southern interior mountain passes beginning Thursday evening. An approaching frontal system will track inland on Thursday and stall across the southern interior. The snow will begin in earnest Thursday evening with periods of snow persisting well into the coming weekend. For Allison Pass, Coquihalla Summit, and Kootenay Pass, initial indications are for 15 to 25 cm of snow on Thursday night. Rogers Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Helmer Lake, and the Okanagan Connector - Pennask Summit are expected to see 5 to 10 cm of snow Thursday night. Strong southwesterly winds aloft will introduce some warmer air to southwestern BC Thursday night, and it is possible that snow will become mixed with rain over Coquihalla Summit and Allison Pass. The heaviest snow is expected to be Thursday night. However, periods of snow will continue into the weekend with additional accumulations likely. In advance of what could be a busy period for holiday travel, please keep an eye on route forecasts and be prepared for winter road conditions. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T14:31:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-18T22:32:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0914271013.2019
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls into tonight. Snow squalls are forecast to persist into the overnight hours. Furthermore, strong northwest winds gusting to 60 km/h will result in blowing snow. Additional local snowfall amounts of 15 to 20 cm are possible by Thursday morning. The snow squalls are forecast to gradually weaken overnight and Thursday morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T17:59:45-00:00

Snow squalls will be possible today as strong winds help snow bands penetrate far inland from Lake Huron and Georgian Bay. Travel may be hazardous at times due to heavy snow and blowing snow reducing visibilities and rapidly changing conditions. Local snowfall amounts of near 10 cm will be possible by late this evening when the snow squalls weaken. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Stagnant winter weather conditions are creating elevated pollution levels. The air quality is expected to improve overnight. ### Individuals may experience symptoms such as increased coughing, throat irritation, headaches or shortness of breath. Children, seniors and those with cardiovascular or lung disease, such as asthma, are especially at risk. If you, or someone in your care, develop symptoms, reduce strenuous outdoors activities where ever possible until the air quality improves. If you are feeling unwell and experiencing symptoms, contact your health care provider for advice. For more information on air quality and your health, please visit the Northwest Territories Department of Health and Social Services at www.hss.gov.nt.ca/en/services/environmental-health/air-quality. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-19T11:30:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services, 2019-12-19T00:32:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3057169017.2019
Area: Inuvik Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Northwest Territories Departments of Environment and Natural Resources and Health and Social Services

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A slow-moving Pacific frontal system will continue to give rain to the West Vancouver Island region tonight. The rain are expected to taper off to a few showers overnight with total rainfall amounts up to 150 mm expected. Rain will redevelop tomorrow as another front approaches. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T13:59:53-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-19T00:25:53-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4213189759.2019

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Overnight lows near -35 C combined with light northerly winds will produce dangerous wind chill values near -45 through the early hours of Thursday morning. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-19T13:36:17-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions have developed this afternoon and are expected to end overnight when winds gradually diminish. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
